https://prez.dev/description.@value: A categorization of disciplines or topics that the broad field of Earth science can be subdivided into, i.e. a listing of the Fields of Research, or subjects, to which a geoscience dataset, publication, observation/activity, or entity pertains. The vocabulary also contains relevant disciplines that intersect with the various Earth science fields, such as biological sciences and built environment and design, as well as entries related to collection and heritage management. Notations included are those from the 2020 ANZSRC listing (see History Note) or in common use in the geoscience community.

Studies related to the search for deposits of useful minerals. It may include geological reconnaissance, geological mapping, remote sensing analysis, geophysical and geochemical methods, and both surface and subsurface (e.g. drilling and underground) investigations. Also studies to establish the nature of a known mineral deposit, in preparatory to development and exploitation; in this sense exploration goes beyond discovery, and is a broader term than prospecting.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The study of concentrations of inorganic, naturally occurring, typically solid, typically non-renewable materials that are of intrinsic economic interest in or on the Earth's crust in such form, quality and quantity that there are reasonable prospects for eventual economic extraction. It includes the study of mineral systems, i.e. the combination of geological processes that are required to form and preserve an ore deposit. Also included is the characterization of orebodies (e.g. quantification of physical properties and chemical properties, and delineation of volumes, grades and geometry), and of limitations to the development and exploitation of mineral occurrences.

https://prez.dev/description.@value: The study of concentrations of inorganic, naturally occurring, typically solid, typically non-renewable materials that are of intrinsic economic interest in or on the Earth's crust in such form, quality and quantity that there are reasonable prospects for eventual economic extraction. It includes the study of mineral systems, i.e. the combination of geological processes that are required to form and preserve an ore deposit. Also included is the characterization of orebodies (e.g. quantification of physical properties and chemical properties, and delineation of volumes, grades and geometry), and of limitations to the development and exploitation of mineral occurrences.

Understanding the combination of geologic processes that are required to form and preserve ore deposits at all scales. It recognises seven critical geological processes: source of mineralizing fluid, source of metals, fluid pathway, thermal gradient, energy source, structural focusing of fluids, and chemical or physical trap for metal precipitation.

Studies related to the process of extracting metallic or non-metallic mineral deposits from the Earth. The term may also include the preliminary treatment of extracted materials, e.g. cleaning or sizing.
The study of economically valuable minerals (ores) in the Earth's crust, including their formation, distribution, and extraction methods.

The field search for valuable commodities, mineral specimens (e.g. gold nuggets, crystals), lapidary material, and mineral deposits â€” usually with the ultimate objective of economic development by mining operations. Prospectors may be divided into two general categories: those with academic, scientific training and those with only field training or in the purely amateur category.

A predictive tool typically used for mineral exploration targeting at the broad regional- to camp-scale. It is less effective and less frequently used at the project- to deposit-scale where predictive tools compete with direct detection techniques. It includes the delineation of prospective areas based on personal experience and interpretation of available geological, geochemical and geophysical data, as well as statistical data analysis/modelling, and in combination GIS-based spatial datasets and/or soft computational models (e.g. fuzzy logic).
